docs.title: About MKC Restaurants
docs.text: MKC Restaurants is the operating group for both Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails in Andover and Grackle in Maple Grove. Both restaurants are family-owned and operated by Becky and Justin Ahlstrom, with deep roots in community service and hospitality excellence.

docs.title: Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails
docs.text:
• Address: 13735 Round Lake Blvd NW, Andover, MN 55304
  • Phone: (763) 205-4762
  • Website: www.margies-kitchen.com

Opened in 2020, Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails is named after Justin's grandmother, Marge, who owned and operated Lyle's Cafe in Winthrop, Minnesota for nearly 40 years. Beyond the home cooking and pies she made Lyle's Cafe famous for, Marge made the cafe the center of her community. We honor her legacy by making Margie's a fixture in the Andover community—a place where everyone is welcome.

docs.title: Grackle
docs.text:
• Address: 11852 Elm Creek Blvd N, Maple Grove, MN 55369
  • Phone: (763) 898-3140
  • Website: www.gracklegrove.com

Grackle opened in October 2024. In naming the restaurant, we felt it was important to maintain a connection to Margie and her community. Grackle Days has been the annual Winthrop town festival since 1985, celebrating the small-town spirit that Grandma Marge embodied.

docs.title: Behavior Expectations
docs.text:
At MKC Restaurants, we expect every team member to:

  • Be Honest
  • Be Kind
  • Achieve Results

These simple principles guide everything we do.

docs.title: Our Mission
docs.text: To provide a safe, supportive, and welcoming environment for our communities to eat, gather, and work. We use the best ingredients, prepare each dish with care, and make sure each guest is seen—creating unforgettable experiences and lasting relationships.

docs.title: Our Values
docs.text:
Consistency: Providing consistent flavors and guest experiences.

Community: Supporting and feeding our community and team. Following the dignity that Margie bestowed on her community and family.

Excellence: Scratch creations based on excellence, full flavors, and a team that is here to serve you.

docs.title: Welcome to MKC Restaurants
docs.text:
Dear Team Member,

Welcome to the MKC Restaurants family! Whether you're joining us at Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails or Grackle, we're thrilled to have you on our team.

When we opened Margie's in 2020, we set out to create more than just a restaurant—we wanted to build a place where our community could gather, celebrate, and feel at home. That vision continues with Grackle, and it's only possible because of team members like you.

We believe that taking care of our team is just as important as taking care of our guests. When you succeed, we all succeed. We're committed to providing you with the training, support, and opportunities you need to grow in your role.

This handbook outlines our policies and expectations, but it's really about one thing: working together to create great experiences for our guests and each other. If you ever have questions or concerns, our door is always open.

Thank you for choosing to be part of our team. We can't wait to see what we'll accomplish together.

Welcome aboard,

Becky & Justin Ahlstrom

Owners, MKC Restaurants

docs.title: Reasonable Accommodations
docs.text: When an applicant or employee needs a reasonable accommodation, MKC Restaurants will seek to provide one. We will make accommodations for applicants and employees who have physical or mental disabilities, individuals who need an accommodation to practice their faith, and individuals who are pregnant or who have pregnancy-related conditions. We will work with applicants and employees to find a reasonable accommodation that allows the individual to perform the essential functions of the position without an undue burden on the Company.

docs.title: How to Request an Accommodation
docs.text:
If you believe you may need an accommodation, contact any manager. We will then work with you through an interactive process:

  1. You describe your needs — Let us know what limitations you are experiencing and what kind of accommodation might help
  2. We discuss options together — We will explore possible accommodations that allow you to perform the essential functions of your job
  3. We may request documentation — In some cases, we may ask for documentation from your health care provider or other professional to help us understand your needs and identify effective accommodations
  4. We implement an accommodation — We will respond to accommodation requests promptly and implement an appropriate accommodation

If an accommodation is not working effectively, let your manager know so we can revisit and adjust as needed.

If you have any questions or need accommodation, please contact any manager.

docs.title: At-Will Employment
docs.text:
Employment at MKC Restaurants is "at will." This means that either you or the Company may terminate the employment relationship at any time, with or without cause, and with or without notice. No contract other than "at will" has been expressed or implied, and no circumstances arising out of your employment will alter your "at will" employment relationship unless expressed in writing and signed by both you and Justin Ahlstrom.

This handbook is intended to provide guidelines and general information about MKC Restaurants' policies and procedures. It does not create a contract of employment, express or implied, nor does it guarantee any fixed terms or conditions of employment.

docs.title: Equal Employment Opportunity
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants enjoys operating in our diverse community. We want to reflect our community to enable every guest to feel welcome. For this reason, MKC Restaurants is committed to being an equal opportunity employer.

MKC Restaurants will not use an individual's age, race, color, gender, gender identity, religion, national origin, disability (mental or physical) status, marital or familial status, sexual orientation, pregnancy, protected military or veteran status, genetic information, status with regard to public assistance, or any other characteristic protected by federal, state, or local law, to make an employment decision. These characteristics will not be used in recruitment, hiring, training, promotion, compensation, demotion, layoffs, recall, termination, or any other employment decision.

Managers have a particular responsibility to prevent and stop discrimination. Managers are required to be aware of this policy, refrain from discrimination, and inform Justin or Becky as soon as they suspect or become aware of an allegation of discrimination.

docs.title: Employee Classifications
docs.text: MKC Restaurants classifies employees based on their work hours and job duties. Your classification determines eligibility for benefits including PTO, health insurance, and other programs.

docs.title: Part-Time Hourly
docs.text: Employees who average less than 30 hours per week.

docs.title: Full-Time Hourly
docs.text: Employees who average 30 or more hours per week.

docs.title: Exempt (Salaried Management)
docs.text: Managers and other employees classified as exempt from overtime requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Exempt employees are paid a fixed salary regardless of hours worked.

docs.title: New Employees
docs.text:
When you are hired, you will be assigned an initial classification based on your expected schedule.

Initial Full-Time Qualification: New employees must average 30+ hours per week during their first 30 days of employment to qualify as full-time.

After your initial 30-day evaluation, your classification will be reviewed according to the quarterly schedule below.

docs.title: Ongoing Classification Reviews
docs.text:
Employee classifications are reviewed quarterly based on hours worked during the prior quarter.

Review Schedule:

Review Date Based on Hours From April 1 Q1: January 1 – March 31 July 1 Q2: April 1 – June 30 October 1 Q3: July 1 – September 30 January 1 Q4: October 1 – December 31

docs.title: Gaining Full-Time Status
docs.text: If you are part-time and your average hours increase to 30+ per week for a full quarter, you will be reclassified as full-time on the next review date.

docs.title: Losing Full-Time Status
docs.text: If you are full-time and your average hours fall below 30 per week for a full quarter, you will be reclassified as part-time on the next review date. See the Time Off Policy and Benefits for how reclassification affects those programs.

docs.title: Regaining Full-Time Status
docs.text: If you lose full-time status, you can regain it by averaging 30+ hours per week for a full quarter.

docs.title: Hours Calculation
docs.text: Average weekly hours are calculated by dividing total hours worked during the measurement period by the number of adjusted weeks in that period.

docs.title: Initial 30-Day Period
docs.text: Total hours worked ÷ approximately 4 weeks.

docs.title: Quarterly Review
docs.text:
Total hours worked in the quarter ÷ adjusted weeks in the quarter.

Adjusted weeks account for days your location was closed. Because Margie's and Grackle may have different closure schedules, adjusted weeks are calculated separately for each location. To calculate:

  1. Start with the total calendar days in the quarter (typically 90–92)
  2. Subtract the number of days your location was closed during the quarter
  3. Divide the result by 7

Example: Q1 has 90 calendar days. Margie's is closed January 1–5 (5 days) while Grackle is closed only January 1–2 (2 days). - A Margie's employee: (90 − 5) ÷ 7 = 12.14 adjusted weeks - A Grackle employee: (90 − 2) ÷ 7 = 12.57 adjusted weeks

Employees who regularly work at both locations will use the closure days of their primary location (the location where the majority of their shifts are scheduled).

This adjustment ensures employees are not penalized for days they were unable to work due to location closures.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about your classification or how it affects your benefits, please contact your manager or HR.

docs.title: Introductory Period
docs.text: The first 90 days of employment are considered an introductory period. This time allows you to learn about MKC Restaurants, your responsibilities, and our expectations. It also gives us an opportunity to evaluate your performance and fit with our team.

docs.title: During the Introductory Period
docs.text:
During this time, you will:

  • Complete all required training and onboarding
  • Learn our systems (Toast, 7shifts)
  • Demonstrate your ability to perform your job duties
  • Show that you can work effectively with our team and serve our guests

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text:
We expect all new team members to:

  • Arrive on time and ready to work for every scheduled shift
  • Be open to feedback and coaching
  • Ask questions when you're unsure
  • Demonstrate our core values: Be Honest, Be Kind, Achieve Results

docs.title: Completion of Introductory Period
docs.text:
Successful completion of the introductory period is not a guarantee of continued employment. Employment remains at-will before, during, and after the introductory period. Completion does not create any right to continued employment or to any particular form of discipline before termination.

After 90 days:

  • You become eligible to use accrued Sick & Safe Time
  • If you've averaged 30+ hours per week, you begin accruing PTO
  • You remain eligible for any applicable benefits as outlined in our policies

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text: In some cases, the introductory period may be extended if additional time is needed to evaluate performance or complete required training.

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text: During your employment, you may have access to confidential information about MKC Restaurants, our guests, vendors, and fellow employees. Protecting this information is essential to our business and required as a condition of employment.

docs.title: What is Confidential
docs.text:
Confidential information includes, but is not limited to:

  • Recipes and food preparation methods
  • Financial information (sales figures, costs, pricing strategies)
  • Guest information (names, contact details, payment information, preferences)
  • Employee information (personal details, wages, schedules, performance)
  • Vendor and supplier information (contracts, pricing, contacts)
  • Business strategies and plans
  • Security codes, passwords, and access credentials

docs.title: Your Responsibilities
docs.text:
• Do not share confidential information with anyone outside of MKC Restaurants
  • Only access confidential information necessary for your job duties
  • Do not photograph or copy recipes, prep sheets, or other proprietary materials
  • Protect guest payment information and never write down full card numbers
  • Respect employee privacy — do not share other employees' personal information with guests without their consent
  • Keep security codes and passwords private

docs.title: Social Media
docs.text: Do not post confidential business information on social media. This includes sales numbers, internal communications, unreleased menu items, or behind-the-scenes content without management approval.

docs.title: After Employment
docs.text: Your obligation to protect confidential information continues after your employment ends. You may not take or use confidential information for any purpose after leaving MKC Restaurants.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you're unsure whether information is confidential or how to handle a situation, ask your manager.

docs.title: Harassment Policy
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants fosters a respectful workplace. We want every employee to treat each other and every guest with respect, even where disagreements may exist. You are free to complain, express frustrations, and disagree, but you must do so respectfully. It is the responsibility of every manager and employee to be respectful.

Harassment is not respectful. Harassment is also against the law. Harassment that is based on an individual's age, race, color, gender, gender identity, religion, national origin, disability (mental or physical) status, marital or familial status, sexual orientation, pregnancy, protected military or veteran status, genetic information, or any other characteristic protected by law will not be tolerated.

Sexual harassment is also prohibited under this policy and under federal and many state and local laws. Sexual harassment includes sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct involving sex. Even though a comment or conduct does not express a sexual desire, comments or conduct may still be sexual harassment.

Harassment is defined as conduct or comments that have the purpose or effect of interfering with an individual's employment. The comments or conduct that could be harassment include:

  • Slurs, epithets, or insults
  • Sexual comments and conversations
  • Demeaning or belittling comments or jokes
  • Displays of offensive or demeaning images, cartoons, or stories
  • Threatening adverse employment actions if sexual favors are not granted or promising preferential treatment in return for sexual favors

MKC Restaurants considers this conduct to be misconduct and will discipline employees who engage in this conduct. The discipline may include termination.

docs.title: Manager Responsibilities
docs.text: Managers are responsible to prevent and stop harassment. Managers are required to be aware of this policy, refrain from harassment, and inform Justin or Becky as soon as they suspect or become aware of an allegation of harassment. If a manager is aware of harassment and does not report the conduct, the manager will be disciplined.

docs.title: Please Tell Us
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants takes allegations of harassment seriously. We encourage applicants and employees to tell any manager if they believe they have been harassed or have witnessed harassment. You may contact them in any manner you feel most comfortable, including via phone, email, in-person discussion, or letter.

If you are uncomfortable reporting to your direct manager — including if they are involved — you may report directly to ownership:

  • Justin: justin@margies-kitchen.com
  • Becky: becky@margies-kitchen.com

MKC Restaurants will keep allegations of harassment as confidential as possible. Only those individuals who need to know will know. That said, it may not be possible to keep all allegations confidential as an investigation and action may be necessary.

docs.title: Investigation
docs.text: When we learn of potential harassment, MKC Restaurants will take appropriate action to stop the conduct. This includes conducting an investigation to learn more about the comments or conduct from those employees or other individuals involved. An investigation may include interviewing individuals, examining various technologies (including email, cell phone, and text records), and reviewing policies. Following the investigation, you will be told of the outcome.

docs.title: Outside Employment
docs.text: MKC Restaurants recognizes that some employees may hold jobs with other employers or engage in freelance work. We respect your right to engage in lawful activities outside of work. While we do not prohibit outside employment, we ask that any additional work does not interfere with your responsibilities here.

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text:
If you have outside employment, you must:

  • Prioritize your scheduled shifts - Your MKC schedule takes priority. Outside work is not a valid reason for calling out or being unavailable for scheduled shifts.
  • Maintain your performance - Outside work should not affect your alertness, energy, or quality of work at MKC Restaurants.
  • Avoid conflicts of interest - Do not work for a direct competitor in a way that could harm MKC Restaurants or create a conflict of loyalty.
  • Protect our confidential information - Never share MKC recipes, business practices, or other confidential information with another employer.

docs.title: Disclosure
docs.text: You are not required to disclose outside employment. However, if your outside work begins to affect your availability, performance, or creates a potential conflict of interest, please discuss it with your manager.

docs.title: Management Employees
docs.text: Managers and employees in leadership roles should discuss any outside employment with ownership to ensure there are no conflicts with their responsibilities.

docs.title: Personal Relationships
docs.text:
Relationships at work can be messy and distract from serving our guests. Although this policy does not prevent the development of friendships, romantic relationships between coworkers, or the employment of relatives, it does establish clear boundaries as to how relationships are conducted at work.

While at work, MKC Restaurants expects employees to keep personal exchanges limited so that others are not distracted or offended by such exchanges. Remember, conversations can be interpreted in many different ways. Conversation—even between consenting adults—can be seen as inappropriate or offensive to others in violation of our Harassment Policy.

Individuals in supervisory/management or other influential roles are subject to more stringent requirements under this policy due to their ability to influence others, affect tenure, promotions, and terms and conditions of employment of their staff.

docs.title: Disclosure
docs.text:
An employee in a management or supervisory position who develops a romantic relationship with someone they supervise or influence must disclose the relationship to ownership promptly. Failure to disclose may result in reassignment of reporting relationships or other corrective action.

Disclosure allows us to address potential conflicts of interest — such as adjusting scheduling, reporting structures, or performance review responsibilities — to protect everyone involved.

docs.title: Retaliation
docs.text: MKC Restaurants will not retaliate against any applicant or employee for reporting concerns, making complaints in good faith, assisting with investigations, filing workers' compensation claims, requesting accommodations, discussing wages, or exercising any other rights protected by law. Retaliation could take on many forms, including intimidation, threats, isolation, demotion, or termination. If you believe this is happening to any applicant or employee, please contact any manager.

docs.title: Safe and Inclusive Work Environment
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants is 100% committed to providing a safe, respectful, and inclusive work environment for all team members. We have no tolerance for behavior that makes coworkers or guests feel uncomfortable.

Our standards of behavior extend beyond the walls of the restaurant—this includes online behavior. Report any concerns to management immediately.

docs.title: Substance-Free Workplace
docs.text:
Employees are not allowed to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol while working. Employees exhibiting signs of being under the influence of drugs or alcohol while working will be subject to immediate discipline, up to and including termination.

There is no tolerance for drinking or using other drugs while working. Working while impaired is unsafe and does not enable us to provide great guest experiences.

MKC Restaurants does not conduct drug or alcohol testing. Discipline is based on observed behavior and work performance.

docs.title: Workplace Violence
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants is committed to promoting the safety of all its employees and maintaining a safe and secure work environment. Acts of violence will result in discipline. Acts of violence include:

  • Stalking
  • Threatening physical or aggressive contact
  • Harassing/threatening calls or messages
  • Other inappropriate hostile behavior against employees that would cause them to reasonably be in fear of their personal safety

In addition to discipline, MKC Restaurants may contact local law enforcement when such conduct occurs.

MKC Restaurants encourages all employees to promptly and accurately report incidents of violence to their manager and/or ownership. No retaliation will be taken against those who in good faith report workplace violence or threats of violence.

Additionally, MKC Restaurants prohibits weapons at both Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails and Grackle locations, including at company-sponsored events, with the exception of hired professional security personnel. This includes concealed weapons for which an employee may have a permit. Employees with valid carry permits may store firearms in their locked personal vehicles in accordance with Minnesota law.

Employees who obtain a restraining order and list Margie's Kitchen & Cocktails or Grackle locations as protected areas are responsible to immediately report this information to management.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants offers the following benefits:

  • Health Insurance (full-time employees)
  • Dental Insurance (full-time employees)
  • Employee Assistance Program (EAP) (all employees)

This policy outlines eligibility and enrollment information. Plan details and costs are available from management during open enrollment.

docs.title: Health & Dental Eligibility
docs.text: Full-Time Hourly and Exempt Management employees are eligible for health and dental benefits. See the Employee Classifications policy for how full-time status is determined.

docs.title: Employee Assistance Program (EAP)
docs.text:
All employees have access to the Employee Assistance Program through AllOne Health, regardless of classification. The EAP provides free, confidential support for personal and work-related challenges, including:

  • Counseling services
  • Work-life resources
  • Financial and legal guidance

Contact information for AllOne Health is available from your manager or HR.

docs.title: Enrollment
docs.text:
Eligible employees may enroll in benefits:

  • During the open enrollment period each year
  • Within 30 days of becoming eligible (new hire or gaining full-time status)
  • Following a qualifying life event (marriage, birth of child, loss of other coverage, etc.)

Enrollment is completed through your manager. Contact your manager or HR for assistance.

docs.title: If You Lose Full-Time Status
docs.text:
If your classification changes from full-time to part-time:

  • Probationary Quarter: Your health and dental coverage continues for one probationary quarter. During this time, the normal cost sharing between you and MKC Restaurants remains the same — your premium contributions continue through payroll deductions as usual.
  • Second Consecutive Quarter: If your hours remain below 30/week for two consecutive quarters, health and dental benefits will end at the close of the second quarter. You will receive information about your options for continuing coverage under COBRA.
  • Return to Full-Time: If your hours return to 30+/week during the probationary quarter, you remain benefits-eligible with no interruption

docs.title: Regaining Eligibility
docs.text:
If you lose benefits due to part-time status and later regain full-time status, you may re-enroll:

  • During the next open enrollment period, or
  • Within 30 days of regaining full-time status (qualifying event)

docs.title: Cost
docs.text: Employees who enroll in benefits share the cost of coverage through payroll deductions. Current contribution amounts are available from HR.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: For questions about benefits eligibility, enrollment, or coverage details, contact your manager or HR.

docs.title: Employee Perks
docs.text: MKC Restaurants offers the following perks to all employees as part of our commitment to taking care of our team.

docs.title: Employee Meals
docs.text: Employees receive one free meal per shift from the employee menu. Employee meals must be consumed on-site and may not be taken home. Meals for family or friends are not included in the employee meal benefit.

docs.title: Employee Discount
docs.text: All employees receive a 50% discount on food purchases. This discount is for the employee's personal use only, requires manager approval, and may not apply to all menu items or specials at management's discretion.

docs.title: Family and Medical Leave (FMLA)
docs.text: MKC Restaurants complies with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), which provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per year for qualifying family and medical reasons.

docs.title: Eligibility
docs.text:
You are eligible for FMLA leave if you have:

  • Worked for MKC Restaurants for at least 12 months (does not need to be consecutive), AND
  • Worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12 months immediately before your leave begins

docs.title: Qualifying Reasons
docs.text:
• Your own serious health condition that makes you unable to perform your job
  • Caring for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition
  • Birth or placement of a child (bonding leave must be taken within 12 months)
  • A qualifying exigency related to a family member's military service

docs.title: How Much Leave
docs.text: You are entitled to up to 12 weeks of FMLA leave in a 12-month period, measured on a rolling basis counting backward from the date you use any FMLA leave. When medically necessary, leave may be taken intermittently or on a reduced schedule.

docs.title: Pay During Leave
docs.text: You are required to use your accrued PTO and Sick & Safe Time concurrently with FMLA leave. Once paid leave is exhausted, the remainder of your FMLA leave will be unpaid. You may also be eligible for wage replacement through Minnesota Paid Leave.

docs.title: Job Protection
docs.text: When you return from FMLA leave, you are entitled to be restored to the same or an equivalent position with the same pay, benefits, and working conditions. Your health and dental coverage continues during FMLA leave on the same terms as if you were actively working.

docs.title: How to Request Leave
docs.text:
• Foreseeable leave: Provide at least 30 days' notice (e.g., expected birth, planned surgery)
  • Unforeseeable leave: Notify your manager as soon as possible

We may request medical certification to support your leave. If your leave also qualifies under Minnesota's Paid Leave program, both will run concurrently — see the Minnesota Paid Leave policy for details.

MKC Restaurants will not retaliate against any employee for requesting or taking FMLA leave.

docs.title: Meal & Rest Breaks
docs.text: MKC Restaurants values employee wellbeing and provides meal and rest breaks in compliance with Minnesota law.

docs.title: Rest Breaks
docs.text: Employees working 4 or more consecutive hours are entitled to at least one paid 15-minute rest break, including sufficient time to use the restroom, within each four-hour period of work. You do not need to clock out for rest breaks.

docs.title: Meal Breaks
docs.text:
Employees working 6 or more consecutive hours are entitled to a paid meal break of at least 30 minutes. The timing of your meal break will be determined by your manager based on business needs.

If you are unable to take your full meal break for any reason, notify your manager immediately.

Employees may voluntarily choose to waive a meal or rest break, but you will never be required or pressured to do so.

docs.title: Scheduling Breaks
docs.text: Managers will work to ensure you receive your entitled breaks. Due to the nature of restaurant work, break times may vary based on business flow. If you are unable to take a break during your shift, inform your manager.

docs.title: Nursing Mothers
docs.text: Nursing mothers are entitled to paid break time and a private space (not a restroom) to express breast milk for as long as the employee has the need. MKC Restaurants will not reduce your compensation for time used to express milk, and you will not face retaliation for requesting these breaks. See our Reasonable Accommodations policy for additional details.

docs.title: Minnesota Paid Leave
docs.text: Minnesota's Paid Leave program provides eligible employees with partial wage replacement when they need to take time off for qualifying reasons. MKC Restaurants participates in the state-run plan administered by the Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development (DEED).

docs.title: Eligibility
docs.text:
You are eligible for Minnesota Paid Leave benefits if you have earned at least $3,900 in wages in the 12 months before your leave begins. This amount can come from one job or be combined from multiple jobs.

Nearly all employees are covered, including full-time, part-time, and seasonal workers.

docs.title: Qualifying Reasons
docs.text:
You may apply for Paid Leave benefits for the following reasons:

Medical leave (up to 12 weeks):

  • Your own serious health condition, including pregnancy and recovery from childbirth

Family leave (up to 12 weeks):

  • Bonding with a newborn, newly adopted child, or newly placed foster child
  • Caring for a family member with a serious health condition
  • Safety leave related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or stalking — for yourself or a family member
  • Qualifying exigency related to a family member's military deployment

Family member is defined broadly under this program and includes your spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandchild, grandparent, and parent-in-law.

docs.title: How Much Leave
docs.text: You may take up to 12 weeks of medical leave and up to 12 weeks of family leave in a 52-week period, with a combined maximum of 20 weeks.

docs.title: Benefit Amount
docs.text: Minnesota Paid Leave provides partial wage replacement — not your full pay. Your benefit amount is calculated based on your average weekly wage. The maximum weekly benefit is set by the state each year.

docs.title: How to Apply
docs.text:
Paid Leave benefits are applied for through the state, not through MKC Restaurants. To file a claim:

  1. Notify your manager that you will be taking leave
  2. Apply at paidleave.mn.gov or by phone at 651-556-7777 (toll free: 844-556-0444)
  3. The state will process your claim and issue payments directly to you

docs.title: Premium Contributions
docs.text: The program is funded through payroll premiums shared between MKC Restaurants and employees. The current premium rate is 0.88% of wages (up to the Social Security wage cap, currently $185,000), split equally — 0.44% employer and 0.44% employee. Your share is deducted automatically from your paycheck.

docs.title: Coordination with FMLA
docs.text: If your leave qualifies under both Minnesota Paid Leave and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), the two will run concurrently. FMLA provides job protection, while Minnesota Paid Leave provides wage replacement. You may be using both programs at the same time.

docs.title: Coordination with Employer-Provided Leave
docs.text: You may use your accrued PTO or Sick & Safe Time to supplement your Paid Leave benefit, up to your regular wages. You cannot receive more than your normal pay by combining benefits.

docs.title: Job Protection
docs.text: If you have worked for MKC Restaurants for at least 90 days, you are entitled to return to the same or equivalent position after your Paid Leave ends. Your health and dental benefits will continue during your leave on the same terms as if you were actively working.

docs.title: No Retaliation
docs.text: MKC Restaurants will not interfere with or retaliate against any employee for requesting or using Minnesota Paid Leave benefits. Employers cannot take your Paid Leave payments. If you believe your rights have been violated, report it to any manager or directly to ownership. You may also contact the Labor Standards Division at the Minnesota Department of Labor and Industry.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
If you have questions about Minnesota Paid Leave, talk to your manager or contact the program directly:

  • Website: paidleave.mn.gov
  • Phone: 651-556-7777 or 844-556-0444 (toll free)
  • Email: paidleave@state.mn.us

docs.title: Pay Schedule
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants pays employees on a bi-weekly basis. Each pay period covers two weeks, running from Monday through the second Sunday. Paychecks are issued on the Friday following the end of each pay period.

If a payday falls on a holiday, you will typically be paid on the preceding business day.

docs.title: Direct Deposit
docs.text:
We encourage all employees to enroll in direct deposit. Direct deposit ensures your pay is available on payday without needing to pick up or deposit a physical check.

To set up or change direct deposit, contact management for assistance.

docs.title: Timekeeping Requirements
docs.text:
Accurate timekeeping is essential. All non-exempt (hourly) employees must clock in and out using Toast.

You are required to:

  • Clock in when you begin work (not before)
  • Clock out when you finish work
  • Clock out for unpaid meal breaks if applicable
  • Clock back in when returning from breaks

You must NOT:

  • Clock in before your scheduled start time without manager approval
  • Have another employee clock in or out for you
  • Work off the clock for any reason

docs.title: Missed Punches
docs.text: If you forget to clock in or out, notify your manager immediately. Your manager will correct the time record. Repeated missed punches may result in disciplinary action.

docs.title: Time Record Review
docs.text: Review your time records regularly through 7shifts. If you believe there is an error in your hours or pay, report it to your manager right away. We will investigate and correct any errors promptly.

docs.title: Payroll Deductions
docs.text:
Your paycheck will reflect deductions required by law (federal and state taxes, Social Security, Medicare) and any voluntary deductions you have authorized (such as benefits contributions).

MKC Restaurants will not make improper deductions from your pay. If you believe a deduction was made in error, report it immediately and it will be corrected.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants recognizes that time away from work is essential to employee well-being, health, and work-life balance. We provide paid time off to support our employees when they need to be away from work.

This policy covers two types of paid time off:

  • Sick and Safe Time (SST): Required by Minnesota law, this time is designated for specific qualifying reasons such as illness, medical appointments, and safety-related absences. All employees are eligible.

  • Vacation/PTO: Additional paid time off for personal use—whether for rest, travel, family events, or any reason you choose. Available to full-time hourly employees and exempt management.

Your eligibility for time off benefits depends on your employee classification. See the Employee Classifications policy for details on how full-time and part-time status is determined.

docs.title: Time Off by Classification
docs.text: Classification Sick & Safe Time Vacation/PTO Part-Time Hourly Accrued up to 48 hrs/year None Full-Time Hourly Accrued up to 48 hrs/year Accrued up to 40 hrs/year Exempt Management Accrued up to 48 hrs/year Accrued up to 80 hrs/year

docs.title: Quick Reference: Scheduling and Pay
docs.text:
Scheduling time off (through 7shifts) and requesting paid time off are two separate steps. The table below shows how common situations work.

Situation Scheduling Paid Time Off Planned vacation or personal day Request off in 7shifts at least 3 weeks ahead PTO only — submit a PTO request through the online form. SST does not apply. Doctor's appointment Request off in 7shifts as early as possible. If the schedule is already published, talk to your manager or find coverage. SST or PTO — submit a request through the online form. Sick day (calling in) Call your manager as soon as possible before your shift SST or PTO — submit a request through the online form. Family member illness or emergency Call your manager as soon as possible before your shift SST or PTO — submit a request through the online form. Planned restaurant closure (holiday) No action needed — you will not be scheduled PTO only (if you want to be paid for the day) — submit a PTO request through the online form. SST does not apply.

Note: Time off in 7shifts is for scheduling purposes only and all shows as unpaid. Requesting paid time off (PTO or SST) is a separate step done through the online form.

Key distinction: Sick and Safe Time can only be used for qualifying reasons (illness, medical care, safety situations, and other reasons listed below). Vacation/PTO can be used for any reason. When a situation qualifies for both, you choose which to use.

docs.title: Sick and Safe Time
docs.text: All employees earn Sick and Safe Time in compliance with Minnesota's Earned Sick and Safe Time (ESST) law. This policy serves as notice of your rights under Minnesota's Earned Sick and Safe Time law. You have the right to accrue and use sick and safe time as described below. MKC Restaurants will not retaliate against you for requesting or using sick and safe time.

docs.title: Accrual
docs.text:
• Rate: 1 hour earned per 30 hours worked
  • Begins: First day of employment
  • Annual Cap: 48 hours earned per year
  • Balance Cap: Up to 80 hours total balance (carryover allowed)
  • Usage Begins: After 90 days of employment

docs.title: Eligible Uses
docs.text:
You may use earned Sick and Safe Time for:

  • Your mental or physical illness, treatment, or preventive care
  • A family member's mental or physical illness, treatment, or preventive care
  • Absence due to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or stalking of you or a family member
  • Closure of your workplace due to weather or public emergency
  • Closure of a family member's school or care facility due to weather or public emergency
  • When determined by a health authority or health care professional that you or a family member is at risk of infecting others with a communicable disease
  • To make funeral arrangements, attend a funeral service or memorial, or address financial or legal matters that arise after the death of a family member

docs.title: Definition of Family Member
docs.text:
Under Minnesota law, "family member" includes:

  • Your child (including foster child, adult child, legal ward)
  • Your spouse or registered domestic partner
  • Your sibling, stepsibling, or foster sibling
  • Your parent, stepparent, or a person who stood in loco parentis when you were a minor
  • Your grandchild, foster grandchild, or step-grandchild
  • Your grandparent or step-grandparent
  • A child, parent, or sibling of your spouse/domestic partner
  • Any individual related by blood or whose close association with you is the equivalent of a family relationship
  • Up to one individual annually designated by you

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text: For absences exceeding two consecutive scheduled workdays, MKC Restaurants may request reasonable documentation. However, you will not be required to disclose specific medical conditions or details about domestic violence situations. Alternative documentation options will be available if obtaining standard verification would create unreasonable burden or expense.

docs.title: Vacation/PTO
docs.text: Vacation/PTO is additional paid time off for personal use. Unlike Sick and Safe Time, you may use PTO for any reason.

docs.title: Full-Time Hourly Employees
docs.text:
Accrual:

  • Rate: 0.0192 hours per hour worked (not to exceed 40 hours per year)
  • Begins: After qualifying as full-time (see Employee Classifications)
  • Balance Cap: Up to 40 hours carryover

If you lose full-time status: PTO accrual stops, but any accrued balance remains available to use.

docs.title: Exempt Management
docs.text:
Accrual:

  • Rate: 3.08 hours per pay period (not to exceed 80 hours per year)
  • Begins: First pay period after hire
  • Balance Cap: Up to 40 hours carryover

docs.title: Requesting Time Off
docs.text:
1. Schedule the time off — Request the day off in 7shifts at least 3 weeks in advance. All time off requests are subject to approval based on business needs.
  2. Request pay (if applicable) — Submit a separate request through the online form for PTO or SST.

For unplanned absences (illness, emergencies), call your manager before your shift and submit your paid time off request afterward.

docs.title: Payout at Termination
docs.text:
• Sick and Safe Time: Not paid out at termination
  • Vacation/PTO: Paid out at termination per Minnesota law

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about your time off balances or eligibility, contact your manager.

docs.title: Tip Policy
docs.text: Tips are an important part of compensation for many of our team members. This policy outlines how tips are handled at MKC Restaurants.

docs.title: Tips Belong to Employees
docs.text: All tips received by employees are the property of those employees. MKC Restaurants does not take any portion of employee tips for any purpose.

docs.title: Credit Card Tips
docs.text: Credit card tips are paid out in cash at the end of your shift. MKC Restaurants does not deduct credit card processing fees from your tips. Credit card tips are automatically reported through the POS system and are subject to applicable taxes.

docs.title: Cash Tips
docs.text: Cash tips received during your shift are yours to keep. You are responsible for reporting all cash tips accurately for tax purposes.

docs.title: Tip Sharing
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants does not operate a mandatory tip pool. As is common practice in the restaurant industry, tipped employees often tip out support staff — such as service support, food runners, barbacks, and service bartenders — in recognition of the teamwork that goes into every shift. Any such tip sharing is voluntary and at the individual employee's discretion.

Managers and supervisors never participate in tip sharing in any capacity, in accordance with federal and Minnesota law.

docs.title: Tip Reporting
docs.text: Credit card tips are automatically reported through the POS system. You are responsible for accurately reporting any cash tips as well. You will receive training on how to report tips through the POS system.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about tips, tip sharing, or how tips are distributed, please speak with your manager.

docs.title: Wage Discussions
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants does not prohibit any employee from disclosing their own wages and will not take any adverse action against an employee for disclosing their own wages or discussing a co-worker's wages, provided the co-worker voluntarily participates in that discussion. Employees are not required to disclose their wages to a co-worker or otherwise, and MKC Restaurants expects all employees to be respectful of their co-workers in this regard.

No form of retaliation shall be taken against an employee who discloses or discusses wages pursuant to this policy. Any employee who believes they have been subject to retaliation in violation of this policy is expected to immediately report that information to any manager.

docs.title: Work Hours & Overtime
docs.text: MKC Restaurants wants to ensure every employee is paid fairly and consistently with applicable federal and state wage and hour law.

docs.title: Work Week
docs.text: For purposes of payroll and overtime calculation, the work week begins on Monday and ends on Sunday.

docs.title: Exempt and Non-Exempt Status
docs.text:
Exempt employees are not eligible to receive overtime pay because they are exempt from the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), state, and local laws. Exempt employees are paid a constant salary regardless of the hours worked.

Non-exempt employees are paid for hours worked; therefore, time worked must be accurately recorded in Toast.

docs.title: Overtime
docs.text:
Non-exempt employees are paid the overtime rate of one and one-half times their regular hourly rate for all time worked in excess of 40 hours in any work week. Overtime payment is based on actual hours worked within a work week. Therefore, any hours worked (up to 40 hours) during a work week that includes a holiday or PTO time will be paid as straight time.

Overtime should be approved in advance by your manager. Employees who work overtime without obtaining proper authorization may be subject to disciplinary action. Regardless of whether the overtime was approved or not, employees will be paid for all hours worked.

Your schedule may be adjusted within the same workweek to ensure overtime is not worked or to reduce overtime. However, once overtime is worked, it must be paid — it cannot be replaced with future time off.

docs.title: Attendance Expectations
docs.text: Fully staffed shifts are essential to our success. Prompt and regular attendance is a condition of employment for all employees. You are responsible for working every shift scheduled or finding adequate coverage. Everyone arrives on time and ready to serve our community.

docs.title: Shift Coverage
docs.text: If you cannot work a scheduled shift, it is your responsibility to find coverage using the shift pool in 7shifts. Keep call-outs to a minimum.

docs.title: Attendance Standards
docs.text:
Attendance issues are evaluated on a case-by-case basis, considering frequency, patterns, business impact, and overall performance. Excessive absences, repeated tardiness, or patterns of calling out (such as consistently missing weekend shifts) may result in disciplinary action.

This policy does not apply to absences protected by law, including Sick and Safe Time, FMLA leave, Minnesota Paid Leave, or other legally protected leave.

docs.title: Call-Out Procedures
docs.text: When unable to report to work due to an illness or emergency, you must contact your manager directly as far in advance as possible before your scheduled shift. In the event of an emergency, notify your manager as soon as practical. Contacting a co-worker is not a substitute for notifying your manager. If your absence extends beyond one day, check in with your manager each day unless otherwise instructed.

docs.title: Scheduling Philosophy
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants builds schedules based on business needs, and assigns shifts based on each team member's ability, availability, and performance. No employee is guaranteed a specific number of hours or shifts per week. Schedules may vary from week to week depending on business volume, staffing needs, and seasonal demands.

Being scheduled for a certain number of hours in one week does not create an expectation or entitlement to the same hours in future weeks.

docs.title: Your Responsibilities
docs.text:
We use 7shifts to manage scheduling. You are expected to:

  • Set your recurring availability and note scheduling preferences in 7shifts
  • Update your availability promptly when it changes so managers can plan accordingly
  • Request time off at least 3 weeks ahead of time
  • Understand that time off requests are not guaranteed

Managers will do their best to consider your preferences, but operational needs come first. Flexibility with your availability — including willingness to work weekends, holidays, and non-prime shifts — is valued and may be considered when building schedules.

docs.title: Schedule Changes
docs.text: Managers may adjust schedules as needed to meet business demands. This may include adding, removing, or modifying shifts. When possible, changes will be communicated in advance, but last-minute adjustments may occasionally be necessary.

docs.title: Servers
docs.text:
• All black base - long pants, professional
  • Clean & pressed apron
  • Black non-slip shoes & socks
  • No leggings or workout gear

docs.title: Hosts
docs.text:
• Business Casual/Professional
  • Closed-toe shoes
  • Appropriate for "church with Grandma"

docs.title: Service Support & Food Runners
docs.text:
• Staff T-Shirt (provided)
  • Long black pants, black socks, non-slip black shoes
  • No sweatpants or leggings

docs.title: All Staff
docs.text:
• Long hair tied back during shifts
  • No strong fragrances
  • Good personal hygiene

docs.title: Kitchen Staff & Food Runners
docs.text:
Per FDA Food Code and Minnesota food safety regulations:

  • Hair restraints required — hats, hairnets, or other approved head coverings must be worn at all times when working in the kitchen; food runners may have long hair tied back on the expo line
  • No artificial or acrylic nails — this includes acrylics, gel extensions, press-ons, tips, wraps, and any other nail enhancements
  • No nail polish (including gel polish)
  • Natural nails trimmed short — must not extend beyond the fingertip
  • Nails must be clean and free of debris

These requirements are based on health code and are not subject to exception.

docs.title: Service Support & Servers
docs.text:
• Nails must be clean and maintained at a short, functional length
  • Staff with artificial nails, gel nails, or nail polish must wear single-use food-safe gloves when handling any food items
  • Nail length must not interfere with job duties or food safety

docs.title: Hosts
docs.text:
• Nails must be clean and professional in appearance
  • Long nail lengths that interfere with job duties are not permitted

Employees in any role who arrive for a shift out of compliance with these standards may be sent home to correct the issue.

docs.title: Uniforms
docs.text:
Front of House: Apron provided at first shift. Brunch t-shirts provided as needed.

Back of House: Shirts provided for up to five shifts each week.

docs.title: Smoking Policy
docs.text: MKC Restaurants is committed to providing a safe, healthy, and smoke and tobacco-free work environment for all guests and employees. MKC Restaurants prohibits smoking, electronic cigarettes (including vaping), and the use of any form of tobacco in all indoor space occupied by guests and/or employees, even during non-work time. There is a designated smoking area for those employees who smoke, use electronic cigarettes, or otherwise use tobacco or nicotine products. All use is restricted to this location.

docs.title: Cell Phones and Personal Devices
docs.text: We understand that employees may need to be reachable during their shift. At the same time, phone use during service impacts the guest experience and your focus.

docs.title: During Your Shift
docs.text:
• Cell phones must not be visible to guests at any time
  • Phone use is permitted only during breaks and in employee areas (back of house, break areas)
  • Phones should be kept on silent and stored in your pocket or personal bag while on the floor
  • Do not use your phone on the floor or in any guest-facing area

docs.title: Emergency Calls
docs.text: If you need to take an urgent call during your shift, step to an employee area away from guests. If you are expecting a time-sensitive call (childcare, medical, etc.), let your manager know at the start of your shift.

docs.title: Earbuds and Headphones
docs.text: Earbuds and headphones may not be worn during your shift. You need to be able to hear guests, coworkers, and safety alerts at all times.

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text: Repeated phone use during service or in guest areas may result in disciplinary action. If you have questions about this policy, talk to your manager.

docs.title: Social Media
docs.text: We love that many of our employees are proud of where they work and share that online. At the same time, our standards of behavior extend beyond the walls of the restaurant — including online.

docs.title: Personal Social Media
docs.text:
You are welcome to post about your experience at MKC Restaurants, including photos in uniform or tagging the restaurant, as long as the content is positive and in good taste. Use good judgment — if you wouldn't want a guest or your manager to see it, don't post it.

When posting, keep in mind:

  • Do not share confidential business information (sales numbers, recipes, internal communications, unreleased menu items). See our Confidentiality policy for details.
  • Do not post content that could be considered harassment, bullying, or discrimination
  • Make it clear that your views are your own and not those of MKC Restaurants

docs.title: Official Accounts
docs.text: MKC Restaurants' official social media accounts are managed by ownership. Do not post on behalf of the restaurant or represent yourself as a spokesperson for MKC Restaurants unless specifically authorized.

docs.title: Your Rights
docs.text: Nothing in this policy is intended to restrict your right to discuss wages, working conditions, or other terms of employment with coworkers, whether in person or online. These discussions are protected by law.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you're unsure whether something is appropriate to post, ask your manager.

docs.title: Technology & Systems
docs.text: Throughout your employment, you will have access to and be required to utilize the following systems. You will be provided links and invites during onboarding.

docs.title: Toast - Point of Sale
docs.text:
Used for:

  • Clock in/out
  • Ordering - utilized on the floor
  • Processing payments

docs.title: 7shifts - Schedules and Communication
docs.text:
Used for:

  • Team contacts
  • Task management
  • Schedules
  • Messages and announcements
  • Availability and time-off requests
  • Shift coverage

docs.title: Payroll
docs.text: Pay stubs, W-2s, and time-off balances are available through our online payroll portal. To set up or change direct deposit, tax withholdings, or other payroll items, contact management.

docs.title: Building Access
docs.text:
Employees who are granted keys and/or security alarm codes are responsible for ensuring that keys and codes are kept confidential and secure. Keys should be stored in a secure location, and codes should not be written down or shared.

By accepting keys or codes, you agree to:

  • Use keys and codes solely for authorized Company purposes and during authorized hours
  • Not share, lend, or duplicate keys or disclose codes to anyone without prior written consent
  • Immediately report any lost or stolen keys or compromised codes to Justin or Becky Ahlstrom at justin@margies-kitchen.com or becky@margies-kitchen.com
  • Return all keys and immediately cease use of any codes upon termination of employment or upon request

Failure to comply may result in disciplinary action, including potential termination of employment. You may also be held financially responsible for any damages or losses incurred due to negligence related to keys or codes.

docs.title: Cut-Resistant Gloves
docs.text: To prevent injuries when using sharp tools, all staff must follow these requirements. This policy applies to all team members, including management and student workers.

docs.title: When Cut-Resistant Gloves Are Required
docs.text:
Mandatory — you must wear a cut-resistant glove (stainless steel if available) when:

  • Operating a meat slicer
  • Cleaning a meat slicer
  • Using a grater or mandoline

Strongly advised — you should wear a cut-resistant glove when using any other sharp, including but not limited to:

  • Knives
  • Peelers
  • Box cutters

Pizza cutters are exempt from this policy.

Management may expand glove requirements to additional tasks at their discretion.

docs.title: Food Protection Guidelines
docs.text:
Cut-resistant gloves prevent injuries, not contamination. Follow these steps every time:

  1. Inspect the glove — check for rips or tears before use.
  2. Correct hand — wear the cut-resistant glove on the hand not holding the sharp tool.
  3. Disposable glove over top — always wear a disposable glove over the cut-resistant glove, without exception.
  4. Change between tasks — change both gloves whenever you switch products or tasks. Always wash your hands when changing gloves.

docs.title: Cleaning & Storage
docs.text:
After each use:

  1. Wash the glove with soapy water by putting it on and rubbing your hands together.
  2. Rinse with clear, warm water from the fingertips toward the cuff. Do not flush water from the inside toward the fingertips.
  3. Air dry completely before storing.

Do not clean cut-resistant gloves in the dishmachine.

docs.title: Emergency Procedures
docs.text:
The safety of our employees and guests is our top priority. Emergency procedures — including fire evacuation, severe weather shelter, medical emergencies, and security incidents — are posted at each location. Familiarize yourself with these procedures and the location of emergency exits, fire extinguishers, and first aid kits.

For fire-specific procedures, including kitchen fire response, extinguisher use, and evacuation, see the Fire Safety policy.

If you have questions about emergency procedures at your location, ask your manager.

docs.title: Fire Safety
docs.text:
Kitchen fires are one of the most serious risks in a restaurant. Every team member must understand how to prevent fires, respond if one occurs, and evacuate safely. This policy covers the essentials — review it carefully, and ask your manager if anything is unclear.

All employees are required to review this policy every six months as part of our ongoing fire safety training.

docs.title: Fire Prevention
docs.text:
The best response to a fire is preventing one. Follow these practices every shift:

  • Keep cooking areas clean. Grease buildup on equipment, hoods, and surfaces is a leading cause of kitchen fires. Clean as you go.
  • Never leave cooking equipment unattended while in use, especially fryers and open flames.
  • Keep flammable materials away from heat sources. This includes towels, paper products, cardboard, aprons, and cleaning chemicals.
  • Report equipment problems immediately. Malfunctioning burners, frayed cords, or faulty pilot lights are fire hazards.
  • Store chemicals properly. Keep flammable products in designated areas, away from heat and cooking equipment.
  • Do not block fire exits, extinguisher access, or hood suppression system controls.

docs.title: Types of Kitchen Fires
docs.text:
Understanding the type of fire determines the correct response:

  • Grease/oil fires (Class K) — The most common and dangerous kitchen fire. Caused by overheated cooking oil or grease igniting. Never use water on a grease fire — water causes grease fires to explode and spread.
  • Electrical fires (Class C) — Caused by faulty wiring, overloaded outlets, or damaged equipment.
  • Ordinary combustible fires (Class A) — Paper, wood, cardboard, or cloth fires.

docs.title: Small, Contained Fires
docs.text:
1. Stay calm. Alert nearby team members.
  2. Turn off the heat source if you can do so safely.
  3. For small grease fires on the stovetop: Slide a metal lid or sheet pan over the pan to smother the flames. Never move the pan.
  4. Use the correct extinguisher if the fire is small and you are trained:
    • Class K extinguisher (silver label) for grease/oil fires — these are mounted near cooking stations
    • ABC extinguisher (red) for general fires
  5. Use the P.A.S.S. technique:
    • Pull the pin
    • Aim at the base of the fire (not the flames)
    • Squeeze the handle
    • Sweep side to side
  6. If the fire does not go out within a few seconds, stop and evacuate.

docs.title: Larger Fires or Hood Suppression Activation
docs.text:
1. Activate the hood suppression system if it has not triggered automatically. The manual pull station is located near each cooking line — know where yours is.
  2. Evacuate immediately. Do not attempt to fight a fire that has spread beyond a single point.
  3. Call 911 once you are safely outside.
  4. Account for all team members and guests at the designated assembly point.

docs.title: Evacuation
docs.text:
• Know your exits. Every location has multiple emergency exits. Familiarize yourself with all of them, not just the one you normally use.
  • Know the assembly point. Your manager will identify the outdoor meeting location for your location.
  • Help guests exit calmly. Direct guests to the nearest exit. Do not allow anyone to re-enter the building.
  • Do not use elevators during a fire.
  • Do not stop for personal belongings.
  • If there is smoke, stay low where the air is clearer.
  • Close doors behind you as you leave to slow the spread of fire and smoke.

docs.title: Fire Extinguisher Locations
docs.text:
Fire extinguishers are mounted in multiple locations throughout each restaurant, including:

  • Near each cooking station (Class K)
  • In the dining room and bar areas
  • Near electrical panels
  • At emergency exits

Know where the extinguishers are at your location. If you notice an extinguisher is missing, discharged, or has an expired inspection tag, report it to a manager immediately.

docs.title: What NOT to Do
docs.text:
• Never use water on a grease fire. This is the most dangerous mistake — it causes a fireball and spreads burning grease.
  • Never try to carry a burning pan outside or to a sink.
  • Never prop open fire doors or block fire exits with equipment or supplies.
  • Never ignore a small fire and assume it will go out on its own.
  • Never re-enter the building after evacuating until emergency responders give the all-clear.

docs.title: Training
docs.text:
All employees must complete fire safety training:

  • At hire — During initial orientation
  • Every six months — Review of this policy and training video

As part of your training, watch this fire safety overview video:

Your manager will document completion of each training session. If you have not completed your semi-annual review, your manager will follow up with you.

docs.title: Reporting
docs.text:
Report any of the following to a manager immediately:

  • Blocked fire exits or extinguisher access
  • Missing, damaged, or expired fire extinguishers
  • Malfunctioning hood suppression systems or fire alarms
  • Grease buildup on hoods, vents, or equipment
  • Any other fire hazard

You will never be penalized for reporting fire safety concerns.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about fire safety procedures at your location, ask your manager.

docs.title: Food Safety
docs.text: The safety of our guests and the quality of our food are top priorities at MKC Restaurants. Every team member plays an important role in maintaining our food safety standards.

docs.title: Our Commitment
docs.text:
We are committed to:

  • Serving safe, high-quality food to every guest
  • Complying with all Minnesota Department of Health regulations and local licensing requirements
  • Maintaining clean, sanitary workspaces
  • Properly training all team members on food safety practices

docs.title: Your Responsibilities
docs.text:
All team members are expected to:

  • Complete required food safety training
  • Follow proper handwashing procedures
  • Handle, store, and prepare food according to established guidelines
  • Keep workstations and equipment clean and sanitized
  • Be aware of allergen concerns and communicate them appropriately

docs.title: Reporting Concerns
docs.text:
If you see a potential food safety issue, report it to a manager immediately.

This includes:

  • Equipment malfunctions (refrigeration, cooking equipment, etc.)
  • Concerns about food quality or freshness
  • Sanitation issues
  • Pest sightings
  • Any situation that could compromise guest safety

You will never be penalized for raising food safety concerns in good faith. When in doubt, ask a manager.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about food safety practices, talk to your manager or refer to your location's food safety training materials.

docs.title: Injury Reporting & Workers' Compensation
docs.text: Your safety is our priority. If you are injured at work, it's important to report the injury and seek appropriate care right away.

docs.title: If You Are Injured at Work
docs.text:
1. Get medical attention - For serious injuries, call 911 or go to the emergency room immediately. For minor injuries, use the first aid kit and inform your manager.

  2. Report the injury - Notify your manager as soon as possible, regardless of how minor the injury seems. All workplace injuries must be documented.

  3. Complete an incident report - Your manager will help you complete an incident report detailing what happened, when, where, and any witnesses.

  4. Seek follow-up care if needed - If you need medical treatment beyond first aid, inform your manager. Workers' compensation may cover your medical expenses.

docs.title: Workers' Compensation
docs.text:
MKC Restaurants carries workers' compensation insurance as required by Minnesota law. If you are injured on the job:

  • Medical expenses for work-related injuries may be covered
  • You may be entitled to wage replacement if you miss work due to the injury
  • You have the right to file a workers' compensation claim

We will provide you with the necessary claim forms and information if you are injured. Retaliation against employees for filing workers' compensation claims is prohibited.

docs.title: Reporting Requirements
docs.text:
All injuries must be reported, even if:

  • The injury seems minor
  • You don't think you need medical attention
  • You're not sure if it happened at work

Early reporting helps ensure you receive proper care and protects your rights under workers' compensation.

docs.title: Return to Work
docs.text: If you miss work due to a workplace injury, we will work with you and your healthcare provider on a return-to-work plan. This may include modified duties or a gradual return to full responsibilities.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about workers' compensation or injury reporting, contact your manager or ownership.

docs.title: Staff Parking
docs.text: Our parking lots are busy and shared by multiple businesses. Reserve spots directly in front of the restaurant for guests. Respect customer parking areas for other businesses. Staff parking areas will be designated by your manager.

docs.title: Discipline
docs.text: MKC Restaurants expects employees to use good judgment at all times. While we don't relish the idea of discipline, sometimes it is necessary.

docs.title: Disciplinary Actions
docs.text:
Discipline may include any of the following, depending on the severity of the issue and the circumstances:

  • Verbal coaching or counseling
  • Written warning
  • Suspension
  • Termination

MKC Restaurants reserves the right to determine the appropriate level of discipline for any situation. Because employment is at-will, any step may be skipped, repeated, or combined based on the circumstances. There is no requirement that discipline follow a particular sequence.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
The following are examples of conduct that may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. This list is not exhaustive:

  • Attendance or punctuality issues
  • Failure to follow policies, procedures, or manager instructions
  • Poor job performance
  • Insubordination
  • Conduct that is unsafe, dishonest, or disruptive
  • Violation of the substance-free workplace, harassment, or other conduct policies
  • Unauthorized use or disclosure of confidential information

Some conduct is serious enough to warrant immediate termination without prior warnings, including but not limited to theft, violence, working under the influence, and harassment.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text: Disciplinary actions may be documented and placed in your personnel file. You have the right to review your personnel file and submit a written response to any disciplinary documentation, as described in the Personnel Files policy.

docs.title: Changes to This Handbook
docs.text: Because the general business atmosphere of MKC Restaurants and conditions are always changing, the contents of this Handbook may be changed at any time at the discretion of MKC Restaurants. No changes in any benefit, policy, or rule will be made without due consideration of the mutual advantages, disadvantages, benefits, and responsibilities such changes will have on you as an employee.

docs.title: Personnel Files
docs.text: MKC Restaurants maintains a personnel file for each employee.

docs.title: Your Right to Access
docs.text:
Under Minnesota law, you have the right to review your personnel file. To request access:

  • Contact any manager to arrange a time
  • Access will be provided within 7 working days of your request
  • You may have a representative present during your review
  • You may request copies of documents in your file

docs.title: Disputing Contents
docs.text:
If you disagree with any information in your personnel file, you may:

  • Submit a written statement of disagreement, which will be included in your file alongside the disputed item
  • Request that incorrect information be corrected or removed

docs.title: Questions
docs.text: If you have questions about your personnel file, contact any manager.

docs.title: Separation of Employment
docs.text: Employment at MKC Restaurants may end for various reasons, including voluntary resignation, termination, or job elimination. This policy outlines the separation process.

docs.title: Voluntary Resignation
docs.text:
If you decide to leave MKC Restaurants, we ask that you provide advance notice:

  • Hourly employees: At least 2 weeks notice
  • Management: At least 4 weeks notice

Notice should be provided in writing to your manager. Providing adequate notice helps us plan coverage and allows for a smooth transition. Employees who provide appropriate notice and leave in good standing may be considered for rehire.

docs.title: Final Pay
docs.text:
Voluntary resignation: Your final paycheck will be issued on the next regular payday.

Involuntary termination: Your final paycheck will be available within 24 hours upon your request, or at the next regular payday, in accordance with Minnesota law.

Final pay will include:

  • All hours worked through your last day
  • Accrued, unused PTO (vacation time) per Minnesota law
  • Any other earned wages

Sick & Safe Time is not paid out upon separation.

docs.title: Return of Company Property
docs.text:
On or before your last day, you must return all company property, including:

  • Keys and access cards
  • Uniforms and aprons
  • Name tags
  • Any other company equipment or materials

Failure to return company property may result in deductions from your final pay to the extent permitted by law, or other collection efforts.

docs.title: Exit Process
docs.text:
Depending on circumstances, your manager may:

  • Conduct an exit interview
  • Review return of property
  • Confirm your forwarding address for tax documents (W-2)
  • Answer questions about benefits continuation (if applicable)

docs.title: Job Abandonment and Inactive Status
docs.text:
No-call/no-show: If you fail to report to work or contact your manager for 3 consecutive scheduled shifts, you will be considered to have voluntarily resigned.

Inactive status: To maintain active employment, you must work at least one shift within any 60-day period. If 60 days pass without working a shift and you are not on an approved leave (such as FMLA or Minnesota Paid Leave), you will be considered to have voluntarily resigned. If you anticipate an extended absence, talk to your manager in advance so we can determine whether an approved leave arrangement is appropriate.

docs.title: Rehire Eligibility
docs.text: Employees who leave in good standing with proper notice may be eligible for rehire. Employees who are terminated for cause, abandon their job, or leave without notice may not be eligible for rehire.

docs.title: References
docs.text: MKC Restaurants will confirm dates of employment and positions held for reference requests. Additional information will only be provided with written authorization from the former employee.
